Rearranging a formula

In the formula for the area of a circle, \(A=\pi r^2\), we say that \(A\) is the subject of the formula. A variable is the subject of the formula if it appears by itself on one side of the formula, usually the left-hand side, and nowhere else in the formula. If we are asked to transpose the formula for \(r\), or solve for \(r\), then we have to make \(r\) the subject of the formula. When transposing a formula whatever is done to one side is done to the other. There are five rules that must be adhered to.

Rearranging a formula:

Key Point

You may carry out the following operations:

  • add the same quantity to both sides of the formula
  • subtract the same quantity from both sides of the formula
  • multiply both sides of the formula by the same quantity
  • divide both sides of the formula by the same quantity
  • take a ‘function’ of both sides of the formula: for example, find the reciprocal of both sides (i.e. invert).

Example

Transpose the formula \(p=5t-17\) for \(t\).

Solution

We must obtain \(t\) on its own on the left-hand side. We do this in stages by using one or more of the five rules in Key Point 22. For example, by adding 17 to both sides of \(p = 5t − 17\) we find

\(\begin{aligned}\qquad p + 17 &= 5t - 17 + 17\\ &=5t \end{aligned}\)

Example

Transpose the formula \(\sqrt{2q}=p\) for \(q\).

Solution

First we square both sides to remove the square root. Note that \(\sqrt(2q)^2 = 2q\). This gives

\(\begin{aligned}\qquad 2q &= p^2 \end{aligned}\)

Example

Transpose \(x=\dfrac{1}{y}\) for \(y\).

Solution

We must try to obtain an expression for y. Multiplying both sides by y has the effect of removing this fraction: Multiply both sides of \(x=\dfrac{1}{y} \text{ by } y\) to get

\(\begin{aligned}\qquad yx &= y \times \dfrac{1}{y}\\ yx &= 1\end{aligned}\)

Divide both sides by \(x\) to leave \(y\) on its own, \(y = \dfrac{1}{x}\).

Alternatively: simply invert both sides of the equation \(x = \dfrac{1}{y}\) to get \(\dfrac{1}{x} = y\)

Example

Make \(R\) the subject of the formula \(\dfrac{2}{R}=\dfrac{3}{x+y}\)

Solution

In the given form \(R\) appears in a fraction. Inverting both sides gives

\(\begin{aligned}\qquad \dfrac{R}{2} &= \dfrac{x+y}{3} \end{aligned}\)

Thus multiplying both sides by 2 gives

\(\begin{aligned}\qquad R &= \dfrac{2(x+y)}{3} \end{aligned}\)

Example

Make \(R\) the subject of the formula \(\dfrac{1}{R} = \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2}\)

Solution

Add the 2 terms on the right: \( \dfrac{1}{R_1} + \dfrac{1}{R_2} = \dfrac{R_2+R_1}{R_1 R_2} \)

Write down the complete formula: \( \dfrac{1}{R} = \dfrac{R_2+R_1}{R_1 R_2} \)

Now invert both sides: \( R = \dfrac{R_1 R_2}{R_2+R_1}\)
